name: Half-Life: Source
description: Winner of over 50 Game of the Year awards, Half-Life set new standards for action games when it was released in 1998. Half-Life: Source is a digitally remastered version of the critically acclaimed and best selling PC game, enhanced via Source technology to include physics simulation, enhanced effects, and more.

First of all this is not a remake (like Black-Mesa), it's a remasterization. Well this is the same old Half Life we all know, except that now it has some improved textures, mainly the metalic ones (incluiding floors), overall lighting, color intensity and all of the character models. The weapons are better looking too as well as your H.E.V. suit (it has nice details on your hands and arms. I recommend it, yes, but only to people that don't own the original or die hard fans like me that would take up any excuse to replay this masterpiece.   The thing that bugs me (ignoring the glitches) is that this remasteriztion feels incomplete. Despite they added physics and the death's are more realistic and satisfying (plus the bullet impact splatter and the bullet holes on characters are a nice detail too) now you CAN'T hit them with the crowbar, it just passes through. The only way to 'hit' the body is hitting the surface were it is and through the bodu. Only then it'll start moving and it is weird because the hit sound it's still the surface one. If they are re-releasing this too, they should have added something extra, like achievements or cards. I also hate that the impact sounds of the crowbar, even when you are smacking wood, it's METAL-HIT-LIKE SOUND. WHAAT????  Finally, I have to say that I played Black Mesa. That is a remake, it has the essence of this game but changed some maps and things (the leechers on the water are gone and the enemies act and react different to the weapons, for example). I liked it and it was a good excuse to travel to Black Mesa again. I still prefer the originall one, but I salute the developers for making an outstanding job at it.

Half Life 1, one of Valve's first games to come to the Source engine.  Common question I get asked, what's the difference between the 'source' and 'non-source' versions?  Really, not a whole lot. Textures look the same, lighting, story, all that. Only things that you will be able to pick out is that the puzzles towards the end are wired differently. This is why I would have someone play the Source version over the goldsource one.  Should you play it? Yes. Do you have to play this to call yourself a PC gamer? Yes. Is it really required or a 'must play'? No.  Many people would not be able to deal with the graphics, puzzles and 'lack of heart pounding action'. Sad to see people turn a title down due to those reasons.  Speaking of graphics, you should be able to run this without problems. If you can't, get rid of Steam. This is as low as the bar gets set on detail and polygon counts.  7.5/10

Half-Life: Source  Run, Think, Shoot, Live.  Developed by Valve and released in 1998, Half-Life was at the time considered the finest first person shooter (fps) of its generation and still remains today one of the best games of all time. After the release of Valves Source engine, like many other of their games, they decided to port Half-Life to it, updating some graphics, fixing bugs and introducing new gun models.   When a mysterious alien artifact is tested at the Black Mesa Research Facility, a Resonance Cascade occurs ripping holes in the fabric of space and allowing aliens from another dimension to pass through to Earth. Awaking in the test chamber Dr. Gordon Freeman must fight his way through Headcrabs, Bullsquids and the powerful Vortigaunts as well as the U.S. Army who has been sent dispose of the Aliens and witnesses.   Half-Life’s plot, although not readily apparent, is extremely complex and dense. It does explain clearly why you need to go from point A to B, however the backstory can be very confusing and still, some of it, remains unresolved to this day. It’s this complexity and mysteriousness that makes the game so much more effective.   Gameplay is one amazing aspect in Half-Life. Being both a puzzle game and an fps, Valve has equality weighted these two genres with lots of little puzzles throughout the game, some hard and some not, as well as lots of fun alien and solider blasting in-between with a large range of cool weapons. Your signature weapon that is now an iconic symbol for the Half-Life franchise is your crowbar, which although not as lethal as a rocket launcher or crossbow, is useful to complete small task like breaking a window or ventilation shaft casing.   The soundtracks in this game always suit the environment and never fail to add to or significantly change the atmosphere of some scenes. The soundtracks consisting of electrical and techno sounds go extremely well with the chapters played in the border world Xen, The creepy number played at the start of the game while in the tram, blew the suspense factors through the roof and nothing goes better with the satisfactory of completing Half-Life than the iconic end credit soundtrack. Unfortunately, after most of the “feel good” soundtracks start you will pass a checkpoint that will que the next sequence and stop the song.   The level design in this game is truly ahead of its time. There is not only significant attention to detail and lots of optional interactivity with the environment, but the game is constantly catching you off guard with jump scares from Headcrabs or collapsing bridges. What contributes to the level design more than anything are the elite graphics. In particular the water in various levels is amazing and hasn’t gotten much better in modern games nearly 20 years later.   Overall this game is an artwork. The storyline is great and only gets better in later games, the gameplay is exciting and fun and the game is made exceedingly better with the incredible soundtracks, level design and graphics. I would recommend this game to anyone but in particular fps gamers as it is a classic and arguably one of the best fps’ of all time. If you buy this game...  Prepare for unforeseen consequences…  9.5/10

Half-Life: Prettier Twin Sister   Pros: Classic, Dialogue, Gameplay, Graphics Cons: Platforming  Originally released in 1998, Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre, winning award after award. The narrative within evolved as allies and enemies would spout little tidbits about the calm, quiet protagonist. Gritty and realistic, gameplay involved a myriad of enemies and traps. Although a completely linear game, the setting varied from huge desert cliffs to claustrophobic air vents.  At the time, most games heavily involved platforming and Half-Life was no exception. Small annoyances can still be found, for example, trying to move along some ladders. Younger crowds might find the graphics outdated and clunky. But these faults are fairly insignificant for a game published more than a decade ago.  A classic, revolutionary title that all FPS fans, serious gamers, and appreciative players should own.  10/10

This is one of the best games I have ever played. Half-Life is a classic that should be played by anyone who appreciates FPS's. In fact, it's your obligation to play this game, because it was the first to do so many things in video games. There are many games that have heavily leaned on the format, gameplay and story telling strategies of this game. The game is very dated, and it shows, but Valve did implement the Source engine which gives it a more polished, free-flowing look. I was able to disregard the dated graphics, because I knew that this was such an original and classic game.   The first half hour of the game is brilliant, because nothing is really happening, but there is an ere tone and feeling that lets you know that something's not right. Some subtle foreshadowing occurs when some of the computers break, and a scientist says the power is going to be switched on to 105%. It's show-not-tell things like this that make the game so gripping and immersive. It's something we don't seem to see in many games anymore.   Anyway, during the first three quarters of the game, you're running around, collecting new weapons, killing aliens, and soldiers sent there to kill you, (a perfectly executed plot twist) solving puzzles, picking up more of the story, riding on rails, launching rockets, blowing up helicopters, storming military bases, navigating mine fields, annihilating green, bangy, tentacle thingies, electrocuting, and blowing up giant, blue flamethrower monsters; the list can go on and on. Basically, you're just having a lot of fun. The constant change of objectives really keeps the player immersed in the game. You never feel like you're repeating the same things over and over again. This is a staple in the Half-Life franchise. Once you start getting bored of something, it changes it up so that you're doing something different and more exciting. The pacing in this game is also phenomenal. It usually goes in the order of: Action event, slow puzzle event, action event slow puzzle event, with some events that feature action and puzzle at the same time, and story exposition sprinkled around and mixed in through everything you do. It's constant fun that never frustrates you or makes you feel cheated.   The subtle rise in difficulty is more subtle than, you know, just changing the color of the monster. It's realistic, and makes you feel the tension rising around the Black Mesa facility. The first three quarters of the game are nearly flawless.  In my opinion, the only downside to this game is the last quarter where you play in the alien world, Xen. This segment of the game really breaks up the immersion. The gravity is toned down, so everything you've gotten used to in the first part of the game is scrapped for a floaty, hard to manoeuvre, way of moving. It's also very slow. From a story telling perspective, it's mind blowing, but from a gameplay perspective, it's quite dull and frustrating. During the chapter Xen, you're just platforming, trying to figure out where to go. Gonarch's Lair was just an annoying, frustrating, slow paced boss fight, But the REAL kicker was interloper.   I hated this level. It was way too long, way too difficult, way to confusing, and way too frustrating. If there was an enemy I could have removed from this game it would be those flying baby thingies, but they were everywhere here and they would respawn all the time! There's never enough health, energy, or ammo for you, so you have too eek by in this extremely hard level. In most levels, if it was hard, it was because you needed to change your strategy. It was your fault if you died. But in this level, there are just way too many overpowered enemies. You're trying to save your health and running out of ammo, and BOOM! You're hit with ten million, flying babies, and bee shooting giants, while being hit with vortigaunt lightning from every corner. The only way to get through this level is to set the difficulty to easy, and die a million times before you memorise where each enemy will be and when he will attack. That's no fun. That's just drudgery.   Nihilanth was just a giant version of those annoying flying babies. Great. To be honest, he was just mediocre. Okay, I do hate how all the Zelda bosses, for example, have huge shiny targets on them that show you exactly where to place a bomb or shoot an arrow, but at least they help you figure out how to defeat it. In Nihilanth, I had no idea how to defeat the monster. shooting it did nothing, and it kept sending me away to these weird caves by throwing portals at me. I was completely lost. I had to go on youtube and see how it was done before I even knew how to kill it. It was still too hard too kill it though. If you play it the way it was intended and jump up onto those cliff things, it's really hard, and he will keep sending portals at you. If you're cheap like me and just hid behind the spiky rocks, then it's easier, but it's painfully repeditive and tedious.  Boss fights in this game were not good with the exception of the green tentacle thing. I will cut it some slack though, because it was kind of a 90's thing to have bosses in your games, and this was a very hard game to put bosses into.  In the last chapter, you're given a monologue from the mysterious G-man, who you may have noticed stalking you throughout the game. He makes you go through a portal, and then the credits hit, reminding you how good the soundtrack in this game was.  All in all, Half-Life was a classic, and should be played by anyone who likes video games. If you like steam you should play this game to show your respects to Valve. It was the first game they made. Half-Life rose to my personal favorite video game franchise after the Metroid Franchise was ruined by Other M. Anyway, just play this game. You have no excuse not to. By the time I picked this game up back in 2004 it was already a old game, but HL is single handedly responsible for me getting back into gaming, and switching from console to PC.  Back when I was a kid I always prayed that one day they would make a videogame that was like a virtual reality where you could move around a real enviornment and interact with objects. Prior to Half-Life I had only played Woffstein3D and doom for PC. Doom was great but it wasn't really interactive or very realistic.   Half-Life was a dream come true and it will always be my favorite PC game of all time.    For all those youngling's out there who grew up with Call of Duty and the like, you probably won't like this game. The graphics are old now, and the pace is slow. However if your still relatively new to gaming then please do yourself a favor and try it. Hell it even has a training room for those who don't have experience controlling a character in first person.   The only difference between HL and HL source is that source has slightly improved lighting and textures in certain areas. The story is explained through small chats with the surviving members of the facility and paying attention to enemy conversations. All the enemy soldiers have an instantly recognizeable scruffy voice while the friendly NPCs sound more calmed and soft, for the most part. This game also has some os the most well known scores for PC games (like the Nuclear Mission jam), and the weapon sounds are very well made. Overall, this game is a classic and a must play for anyone who enjoys videogames.

This is basically  Half-Life  with an actual physics engine. As it is, this version is more for people who want to experience Half-Life with some more modern conceits. (The Source version of Half-Life Deathmatch is  separate .)  The physics engine in question is Valve's Source engine, which means adjustable field-of-view, higher resolution displays, ragdoll physics, and more realistic water that you can see into somewhat (which  kind of  ruins the scenes with the Icthyosaurs, kind of). There is also Oculus Rift support.  The MP5 functions slightly differently: it bounces up and down more in your hands when it fires, and the bullets fly accordingly. The weapons, IMO, are even more satisfying overall than in the original version.  The port itself isn't stellar. There are some texture, scripting and AI glitches that you may or may not experience. I clipped out of the tram in the beginning once!   Aside from an optional HD texture pack, the ability to use certain game assets in Garry's Mod, the ability to start a new game from any chapter, and animated menu screens displaying scenes from the game...that's it. Those are the only things separating HL: Source from the original game. It's interesting overall, and I think it  feels  great if not better than the original game, but this is by all means more of an enthusiast purchase. Ross Scott used it to make  Freeman's Mind  [www.accursedfarms.com] , at least.  Others were more disappointed after the initial release. That spurred the development of a fan-made recreation called Black Mesa, which is much more of a modern remake. It's free for download  here  [www.blackmesasource.com] , and a paid version with Steam features is available on Steam  here .

So this is the first time I have ever played a Half-Life game, and in my first 2 hours of playing, I can say that this game is fantastic. It does not have 10 to 20 minute cutscenes with loads of dialogue, nor is it a team multiplayer that you respawn in several times per round, but it is the beginning of the fps with a plot and the chaotic environment of Portal 2, which coincidentally both use valve's Source engine, albeit rougher image quality in Half-Life because it has been ported to this engine while it was in its early days. It does become a little addicting once you start playing because you start at ground zero and have to work your way out of  hell  the facility to escape while others around you are much less fortunate. It isn't the prettiest game out there, nor is it one with a story so intricate that writing it down would result in a book larger than the Harry Potter series, but it is gripping enough that just by playing the first game, (and Half-Life can never be mention without mentioning Half-Life 3) I can understand why fans want a Half-Life 3. Plus the whole series is available for less than $10 during sales (I got mine during the Winter 2016 sale).
